conclusion: To solve the problem, calculate the speed of the block as it slides from point A to point B using the conservation of energy, then determine the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B.

The image shows a smooth circular track with points A, B, and C. Point A is at the top of the track, point B is at the bottom, and point C is vertically above point B. The track has a radius of 0.8 m, and the conveyor belt is horizontal, with a motor driving it in the direction shown.
The block is released from rest at point A, so its initial potential energy is m × g × 0.8.
At point B, the block's potential energy is m × g × 0.6.
The difference in potential energy is converted into kinetic energy: m × g × 0.8 - m × g × 0.6 = m × g × 0.2.
This energy is equal to the kinetic energy of the block at point B: (1/2) m × v_B^2 = m × g × 0.2.
Solving for v_B, we get: v_B = sqrt(2 × g × 0.2) = sqrt(0.4 × 10) = sqrt(4) = 2 m/s.
At point B, the block is on a horizontal conveyor belt, so the only force acting on it is the kinetic friction force, f_k = μ_k × m × g = 0.1 × m × 10 = 0.1m × 10 = 1 N.
The supporting force N at point B is equal to the gravitational force m × g minus the friction force: N = m × g - f_k = m × 10 - 1 = 10m - 1.
The ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force is: N/(m × g) = (10m - 1)/(10m) = (10 - 1)/10 = 9/10.
The speed of the block when it slides from point A to point B is 2 m/s. The ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B is 9/10.
